So in 1997, Apple finalized the deal to acquire Steve Job's company, NeXT. And the powerful technologies inside the Unix based NeXTSTEP slash OpenStep operating system. This gave birth to a rewritten Mac OS named, Mac OS X with new technical features such as preemptive multi-tasking, protected memory and killer graphics capabilities with the Quartz imaging model. On top of that, Mac OS X ushered forth a new user interface to replace Mac OS 9's platinum named, Aqua. Bottom line, Mac OS X was gearing up to be a stable, powerful and user-friendly OS with the goal of marrying the power of Unix with the simplicity of Macintosh. But it came at a price. Classic Mac OS apps that ran on version nine and earlier would not inherit the new features, the new interface or the new technical benefits. None of that would work. However, Mac OS X could still run those apps in the Classic environment as is. The good news is Apple introduced Carbon APIs. Steve Jobs said one of the design goals was when you see it you want to lick it. Semi-transparent menus and title bars were present throughout the system. This was something no other consumer OS offered on the market. We take drop shadows and translucent graphics for granted today. But in 2001, this was practically unheard of.
